entry.title: Charts
Cupid Spell and the Duality Magic: A Peek Backstage at the Dream Logic of "Look Alike"
entry.summary: There is a properly oddly compelling nature to Cupid Spell's first single Look Alike. The song seems to have wandered…
entry.content:
There is a properly oddly compelling nature to Cupid Spell's first single Look Alike. The song seems to have wandered out of the Red Room of Twin Peaks, its synths aglow like neon in mist, its vocals walking the blade's edge between knowing and terror. It's a synth-pop daydream in dark hues constructed in homage to David Lynch, but what keeps it from succeeding is the manner in which it glides so easily into his world of contradictions, where beauty and terror, lust and fear, exist in the same pale light.

Cupid Spell, the duo of Josh Kreuzman and Mandy Buffington, was formed earlier this year in Bloomington, Indiana. Josh, familiar to darkwave enthusiasts as solo artist Twice Dark, and Mandy, author and creative partner, collided with mutual fascination with love, loss, and the bizarre poetry in between. They collided on a whim, responding to a call to produce an original work for the tenth issue of Lover's Eye Press, a folio dedicated to the surrealist genius of Lynch. The result is Look Alike, a song that doesn’t simply pay homage to its inspiration but extends his world through sound, as though Badalamenti’s dreamlike chords and Julee Cruise’s spectral melodies were filtered through a new dimension.

The track opens like a mirage. A pulsing synth line shimmers in the distance, its rhythm patient and hypnotic. As it solidifies, voice-sampled from Lynch's Number of the Day series wafts in on the wind like an incantation, situating in his distinctive voice. The song wraps around it, Kreuzman and Buffington building a sound world of dark harmonies and hushed confession, sketching motifs of duality, duplicity, and the unnerving notion that we all contain two selves. A tribute and a question: if we are all mirrors, whose reflection?

The track possesses a filmic stillness. You can almost see the pan of the camera over misty pine forests or the motionless beam of a motel sign in the middle of the night. Kreuzman's synth work makes use of the creepier romanticism of Angelo Badalamenti's soundtracks, but the sound does possess a very clear modernity, contained within a minimalist beat that takes from darkwave and contemporary synth-pop equally. Buffington's is a sigh on the pillow of fantasy, distant yet anchored in a tender despair that speaks both of nowness and remoteness. They create a sound world haunted not by specters, but by remembrance and possibility.

Look Alike is remarkable not simply because of its literal visual verisimilitude but also because of its metaphysical slant. The work is not simply borrowing from Lynch's preoccupation with the double; it abides there. Its melody glides in opposing directions simultaneously, seductive and menacing, human and mechanical. There is tactileness to its sound, yet also a keening edge of division, as if the record itself were posing the question of whether it is ever possible for authenticity to exist within such an image-overloaded and copycat world.



While the roots of Cupid Spell are in this one, there is already an air of evolution. There has been some sketching out of future content by Kreuzman and Buffington, and a string of singles as far ahead as 2025 and 2026. If Look Alike is anything to go by, then Cupid Spell is keen on creating a mood, a mood that stays long after the last note disappears.

Ultimately, Look Alike is a record scored to dream sequences. It's darkly romantic and cinematic and quietly knowing, asking listeners to linger in the threshold room between fantasy and realization. You can approach it as a David Lynch fan, a synth-pop aficionado, or just a fan of songs that can't be solved easily, but Cupid Spell is a thing of brutal beauty that makes you squirm. When the last remnants of Lynch's voice, sampled into the song, disappear into nothing, there is only one thing left to ask: when you look into the mirror of this song, who looks back?

entry.title: A conversation with Junifer
entry.summary: Where can we find you right now and what are you up to? Welp, ever since releasing my first album…
entry.content:
Where can we find you right now and what are you up to?

Welp, ever since releasing my first album in March, I've been working to release a new song about every month or so. It's been a fun exercise in keeping the momentum and creativity going, especially since this isn't my day job, so I've got to find time (typically in the wee hours of the night) to make music. I've begun experimenting with adding more visual content with my music, which wasn't ever something I had experience doing before and it's been cool to develop that out a bit. 
 
How would you define success? What is your goal?

I used to think success was to get the community at large to validate your artistry or something, but now I think that's dumb, and success to me feels like allowing yourself the space to make art and share it, regardless of how many people that reaches. Especially when you can bring your buddies along to make music together, I don't think it gets much better than that. I'll always struggle with trying to reach a larger audience to allow more of my time to spend making music, but my hope is to never let that get in the way of just making things I like with folks I like.

 

 How did you start?

I've always been making music on my own and with friends, and though I had ambitions to make it more legitimate, It was never my primary focus. Life never really allowed space for it properly, and I didn't have a good pathway to get there either. The biggest change that allowed me to start was having my buddy Matt provide really good input and discernment on the songs I was developing, and then meeting my audio engineer Brandon Brown. That gave me a great runway to actually put out music that I thought sounded pretty solid. 

What is a typical day in your life as an artist?

As an artist? Extremely limited. I've got a family and a job, so any time spent doing artist stuff is mostly in the cracks. Primarily at night after my kids go to bed. I'm working to carve out a tiny bit of room during the day each week to spend more time on it. So for now, most of my "artist" time is either me at my little workstation chunking away at tracks in various stages of development, or spending too much time learning how to do promotion and marketing myself (which I'm bad at and don't like doing!). But the little moments when I'm working on a song and things start coming together well and it hits you in the feels...those are the moments I hold on to and get excited about sharing with others. 

If your song were to be included in a movie, which one would you choose?

Oh boy, I love movies. Right now, the best thing I've seen lately is 28 Years Later, it's incredibly moving in a semi-deceptive way and really speaks to our humanity and how careful we must be not to lose it, especially in the way we care for others. I know that wasn't the question, but the more I can promote how wonderful and contemplative that movie is I will! I think the latest song I released (Thoughts For The Night) would be swell for reflective moments in a nice little indie movie or something!

What do you think of AI in music?

AI terrifies me. It's surreal seeing how quickly the technology is changing, and the various applications that are continually released in how AI can be utilized across the board. It will be interesting to see how things develop. I know distributors and other platforms like Spotify are doing their best in protecting AI from fully disrupting the music artist space. However, you continue to hear stories of fully AI artists gaining large following and streams, and you realize it's taking attention away from talented artists who are putting in effort to create their music. There's definitely some interesting capabilities AI can have in music and creative development, but we have to be careful with how it's applied and what it may be exploiting, especially when the technology seems to be outpacing its regulations. I'm curious and nervous to see where things go, and how creative folks are able to protect their art and still make things the public want to listen to without it being overshadowed by fully developed AI music.  

Tell us about your latest or upcoming release.

My latest release "Thoughts For The Night" came out in early October, so I've been focused on promoting that. As I mentioned earlier, I'm still working to release a song about every month or so (at least till the end of the year), so I've got a few more songs I'm working on and I'll see which one shakes out the soonest to be my next release. I've also started working on alternate versions of songs I've released already which has been fun. So stay tuned for more to come...

Austin Lowman Paints the Night in “Velvet”

With “Velvet,” Austin Lowman invites listeners into a shadowy dreamscape where introspection meets slow-burning rock. This haunting ballad drapes itself in mellow guitar riffs and emotive vocals, crafting an atmosphere both tender and chilling.

The track unfolds like a midnight confession—low-lit, honest, and soul-stirring. Perfect for solitary moments, “Velvet” lingers long after its final note, echoing like a distant memory.

 

Andreas Klamm’s “Love Will Lead Thy Way” Offers a Global Message of Hope and Connection

With a voice rooted in compassion and a career spanning over 30 years of music and advocacy, Andreas Klamm returns with a stirring new single, “Love Will Lead Thy Way.” This poignant love anthem, released internationally on all major streaming platforms, echoes a timeless message: that love is the compass guiding us through life’s storms.

A renowned German-French singer-songwriter, journalist, and humanitarian, Klamm once again blends soulful lyrics with heartfelt melodies, delivering a track that speaks to the emotional core of listeners from every corner of the globe. Known for his poetic storytelling and deep emotional resonance, Klamm describes the song as “something that offers comfort, encouragement, and a sense of connection in times when the world needs it most.”

“Love Will Lead Thy Way” is not just a song—it’s a gentle call to unity, a reminder that even in the face of division and uncertainty, love remains our most powerful force. With lyrics that uplift and a melody that lingers, the track captures Klamm’s signature sincerity and global perspective, shaped by decades of work not only as a musician but also as a vocal advocate for human rights and peace.

April Top Releases

Track of the month

 

Shards – Not a Dancing Song: When Love Hurts and Heals

From the sun-drenched streets of Naples comes a voice that wears its heart on its sleeve. Meet Shards, a 29-year-old independent solo artist who writes, sings, and produces every beat of his truth. Deeply inspired by the emotive genius of George Michael, Shards channels that same vulnerability and soul into his latest release, Not a Dancing Song—out now, as of April 4th.

Featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New April Vol 2 (Printed Version)

New Laconia – The Fates: A Cosmic Dance of Destiny

In 2025, a new musical universe emerged from Ukraine—New Laconia, a genre-blending project that defies convention and delights the imagination. Helmed by visionary Alex Syniakov, this bold creation fuses heavy metal, rock, jazz, pop, and cinematic storytelling into something entirely fresh. With its debut single, Stardust Bear Bazaar, New Laconia invited listeners into a sci-fi dreamscape: a timeless pub at the edge of the universe, run by a cosmic barkeep named Bear, tangled in time loops and interdimensional mayhem.

Featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New April Vol 2 (Printed Version)

ABOUT MONSTERS Unleash the Haunting Intensity of "Suffocate"

German metal/post-hardcore outfit ABOUT MONSTERS return with Suffocate, their latest single under Redfield Records. A brooding and relentless track, Suffocate delves into the harrowing grip of toxic relationships—where manipulation, emotional detachment, and suffocating pressure slowly erode one’s sense of self.

Crafted by guitarist Florian Brunemann and vocalist Madeleine ‘Maddy’ Wiebe, with additional contributions from Julian Breucker (Smash Into Pieces, Future Palace, Annisokay, Beyond The Black), the single thrives on a fusion of crushing riffs, searing vocals, and an unshakable chorus. With Breucker spearheading production and Christoph Wieczorek (Annisokay, Electric Callboy, Future Palace) handling mixing and mastering, Suffocate delivers an unfiltered emotional gut punch, capturing the weight of despair and the fight for self-preservation.

Recorded in 2024 at Sawdust Recordings in Halle (Saale), Germany, Suffocate is the latest step in ABOUT MONSTERS’ sonic evolution. The band—comprising Wiebe (vocals), Brunemann (guitar), Sönke Heuer (guitar), Torben Heuer (bass), and Alexander Tepe (drums)—has solidified their reputation for blending raw aggression with haunting melody.

"Suffocate" is featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New April Vol 1 (Printed Version)

March Top Releases

Michelle Calder Unleashes a Storm with Her Haunting Folk-Pop Anthem

A tempest of raw emotion and cinematic sound design, Michelle’s latest folk-pop anthem isn’t just a song—it’s an experience. Channeling the forces of nature, this evocative track mirrors the chaos of a love gone wrong, weaving a sonic landscape that builds and crashes like an actual hurricane.

From the moment the first gust sweeps in, listeners are transported into a swirling storm of ethereal melodies and atmospheric echoes. Real hurricane winds howl through the track, carrying Michelle’s haunting vocals like a whisper through the eye of the storm. The song’s structure masterfully mimics the rhythms of a hurricane, with a chilling stillness at its core before the turbulence resumes, punctuated by the delicate chime of Michelle’s own wind instruments.

Hurricane is featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New March Vol 2 (Printed Version)

Arcane Lullaby: A Sonic Journey Beyond Boundaries

Hailing from Santa Cruz, California, Arcane Lullaby is anything but ordinary. With two full-length albums mixed by Grammy-nominated, multi-platinum producer/engineer Ulrich Wild, Arcane Lullaby’s music is as polished as it is thought-provoking.

Nobody's Business is featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New March Vol 2 (Printed Version)

"The atmosphere is immersive, evoking a sense of nostalgia and raw vulnerability while maintaining a timeless appeal. This is the kind of song that lingers long after it ends—a track with undeniable hit potential. We’re thrilled to feature it in our upcoming print edition and will be sharing it across our Instagram as well."

Nobody's Business is featured in the printed issue of Indiefferential What's New March Vol 1 (Printed Version)

January Top Releases

795: Redefining Boundaries with Emotional Resonance and Raw Energy


Meet 795, an artist who defies conventions and rewrites the rules of music. Known for crafting genre-blending tracks that hit straight to the core, 795 is more than just a musician—they’re a storyteller, weaving personal experiences into every melody and lyric. With authenticity and raw energy at the forefront of their creative vision, 795 has carved a space in the industry that is both distinctive and deeply relatable.

 

Full feature is also be available in print in Indiefferential What's New January Vol. 1 available now!

 

Shards Elevates Pop with New Single 'Elevator

 

Naples-based independent artist Shards is making waves with the release of their brand-new single, Elevator, which is now available worldwide on all streaming platforms and digital stores. At just 29 years old, Shards has built an impressive reputation as a self-sufficient creative force, writing, singing, and producing their own music. With a vocal range that embraces multiple genres but a heart rooted in pop, Shards cites the legendary George Michael as their all-time favorite inspiration.

Full feature is also be available in print in Indiefferential What's New January Vol. 1 available now!

December Top Releases

Rita Mercury Unveils "Hurricane (Reimagined)" – A Storm of Passion and Resilience

Following her powerful debut with “Nobody,” Rita Mercury returns with her captivating new single, “Hurricane (Reimagined).” This evocative ballad, layered with a light rock edge, pairs Mercury’s exquisite vocals with a rich instrumental palette of soft guitar, delicate piano, and resonant bass lines.


“Hurricane (Reimagined)” unfolds the tale of a love as tumultuous as it is passionate. “Our love is a hurricane, turbulent and wild. Don’t let go of my hand, don’t leave me behind,” Mercury sings, drawing listeners into a heartfelt journey of resilience and hope. The song’s lush metaphors and vivid imagery explore the fragility and beauty of human connection, creating an emotional resonance that lingers long after the final note.

With its blend of sensuality, depth, and emotional honesty, “Hurricane (Reimagined)” continues to solidify Rita Mercury’s place as an artist who fearlessly wears her heart on her sleeve. Her music inspires listeners to embrace the storms of love and find strength amid the chaos.

Full feature of  "Hurricane (Reimagined)" , is also be available in print in Indiefferential Picks January Vol. 1 available now!

December Top Releases

 

Louise Goffin: Brooklyn-Born, Laurel Canyon-Souled

Brooklyn-born multi-instrumentalist and singer-songwriter Louise Goffin has always been deeply curious about music’s power to connect and transform. With creativity coursing through her veins, thanks to her renowned songwriter parents Carole King and Gerry Goffin, Louise grew up in an environment that was as inspiring as it was complex—her father’s bipolar disorder adding layers of depth and introspection to her artistry.

Now in what she describes as the most fulfilling phase of her career, Louise’s music continues to blossom in unexpected ways. Drawing inspiration from the rich legacy of Laurel Canyon, her lyrics are deeply personal and introspective, reminiscent of the storytelling giants she grew up admiring.

 

Stephen Dowd, a talented Canadian songwriter based in Ottawa, Ontario, has been steadily carving his path in the music scene with his heartfelt lyrics and eclectic musical style. Over the course of 2024, he has recorded and released three captivating tracks, each showcasing a unique blend of genres and his evolving artistic vision.

The journey began in May with the release of “You’re Beautiful To Me,” a tender ballad that resonated deeply with listeners for its sincere lyrics and emotive delivery. Dowd followed up in August with the energetic Pop/Rock anthem “Heaven Won’t Wait,” a collaborative effort co-written with Gareth Auden-Hole. This track added a dynamic edge to his repertoire, blending infectious rhythms with introspective storytelling.

Now, Dowd has taken a bold step into the Dance/Pop realm with his latest single, “(Ça S’en Vient) It’s Coming Can You Feel It.” This third release marks a significant departure from his earlier work, showcasing his versatility and ability to craft songs that pulse with energy and excitement.

 

Fuentes De Vida, a bilingual singer-songwriter from Brooklyn, New York, crafts a sonic landscape where raw alternative rock meets introspective, socially charged storytelling. Drawing inspiration from icons like Patti Smith, Björk, Imagine Dragons, and Nirvana, the music intertwines bold energy with themes of addiction, grief, love, and human connection. Each track is designed not just to be heard but to resonate deeply, sparking reflection and connection.

Full feature of "Alice's Descent", also available in print in Indiefferential Picks December Vol. 1, out now!

The upcoming album, Alice Down the Rabbit Hole, ventures into the chaotic labyrinth of the modern world. Themes of disinformation, societal division, and the blurred boundary between truth and fiction form the backbone of this Wonderland-inspired narrative. Explosive riffs, unforgettable hooks, and thought-provoking lyrics challenge listeners to examine their perception of reality while immersing them in an intense and immersive musical journey.

November Top Releases

Discover the hottest releases handpicked by our team, curated exclusively for you! Don’t miss these standout features, also available in print in What’s New? November Vol. 4, out now!

 

TheJuZShoW Debuts Within the Vision: A Bold Evolution in Alternative EDM

Crafted entirely by TheJuZShoW herself, the 12-track project showcases her skills as a writer, producer, mixer, and master of her craft. With vocals recorded in her home studio, Within the Vision isn’t just an album—it’s a sonic manifesto.


“This album is like nothing I’ve ever written before,” she explains. “It’s the sound I’ve always been chasing—a step in the right direction, both creatively and personally.”

Drawing influence from industrial, electronic, and alternative titans like Jean-Michel Jarre and KMFDM, the record delivers a rich, immersive listening experience. Each track pulses with a unique energy, blending haunting melodies, thunderous beats, and introspective lyrics that redefine the boundaries of modern EDM.

With Within the Vision, TheJuZShoW invites listeners into her world—a place where innovation reigns, and every track tells a story worth hearing. Don’t miss the chance to experience her bold debut for yourself.

 

Social Gravy Returns with Electrifying New Single, “Lone Wolf”

Social Gravy, helmed by Brad Kohn and Vee Bordukov, roars back onto the scene with their first release since 2020: “Lone Wolf.” This high-energy, riff-driven track is just the beginning of a new chapter for the band, as they gear up to release a series of singles culminating in a highly anticipated EP.

Clocking in at just over two minutes, “Lone Wolf” is a sonic firecracker. Rooted in the swagger of Aerosmith, the grit of Soundgarden, and the bluesy allure of The Black Keys, the track hooks listeners with its infectious core guitar riff and thundering rhythm. Brad Kohn’s commanding vocal delivery adds depth, pouring emotion into lyrics that explore themes of longing and escape. Lines like, “It’s a long way just to love you, short shot to the moon,” highlight Social Gravy’s knack for blending raw intensity with heartfelt melodies.

Known for their riff-heavy yet deeply melodic sound, Social Gravy has carved out a niche as “romantic rock’n’rollers” who balance high-energy tracks with emotional authenticity. Their past work, including the acclaimed 2017 album Behind Every Yes and the 2020 EP A Different Kind, earned praise from outlets like The Big Takeover and Spill Magazine, with the latter describing their music as “quality rocking pop.”

“Lone Wolf” continues this legacy, spotlighting the band’s ability to craft memorable, emotionally resonant tracks without compromising their indie rock roots. With a sound that’s both nostalgic and refreshingly modern, Social Gravy remains dedicated to keeping the spirit of rock alive.

Available on all major streaming platforms starting November 22, 2024, “Lone Wolf” promises to set the stage for an exciting new era of music from Social Gravy.

Dasvibes and Wiski D Light Up the EDM Scene with Explosive New Single Bring Dat Come

International music innovators Dasvibes (DJ Wade) and Wiski D are making waves with the release of their electrifying EDM dance track, Bring Dat Come. Dropping on all major streaming platforms on November 22, 2024, this high-energy anthem fuses EDM’s pulse-pounding beats with the vibrant rhythms of Caribbean dancehall. The track, mastered by legendary engineer Leon Zervos at the iconic Studios 301 in Sydney, promises a polished and powerful sound that’s destined to ignite dance floors worldwide.

Bring Dat Come stands as a bold departure for Dasvibes and Wiski D, pushing the boundaries of their artistic style. While their previous hit, Bring That Come, leaned heavily into dancehall, this track ventures into the exhilarating world of EDM, showcasing Dasvibes' innovative production techniques and Wiski D’s commanding lyrical delivery. Together, they create a seamless blend of global sounds that captures the essence of both genres.


With Leon Zervos’ expert mastering—a name behind hits from Maroon 5, Muse, and Aerosmith—the track is elevated to new heights. Zervos' touch ensures a crystal-clear and explosive sound that’s ready for clubs, festivals, and playlists alike.

Dasvibes, an Australian-Jamaican DJ and producer based in Brisbane, is celebrated for blending his Jamaican roots with cutting-edge electronic music. Renowned for his inventive sampling and energetic live sets, Dasvibes continues to redefine EDM with his genre-defying approach.

Wiski D, hailing from Kingston, Jamaica, is a rising star in the dancehall scene. Influenced by the infectious rhythms of 90s dancehall and his Christian upbringing, he has carved out a unique space in the genre. His innovative style and magnetic stage presence have positioned him as a global voice for contemporary dancehall.

Actor-Turned-Singer-Songwriter David Raine Steps Into the Spotlight with Soulful New Singles

David Raine has spent years captivating audiences on screen, but the seasoned TV and film actor is now channeling his storytelling talents into music. With a history as a singer-songwriter that predates his acting career, Raine’s passion for music has long been a deeply personal endeavor. Over the years, he’s contributed songs to soundtracks and written for other artists, but now, he’s stepping into the spotlight with a series of solo releases that showcase his introspective, thought-provoking lyricism.

Raine describes his songwriting style as contemplative, often weaving clever imagery into lyrics that reflect how he communicates in real life—authentic and meaningful. His recent releases, PRAY and ORION, are already making waves, offering a glimpse into his knack for pairing poetic depth with relatable emotion.

Next up is SILENT, a hauntingly beautiful piano and guitar ballad slated for release on December 6, 2024. This track promises to be a standout moment in his growing discography, blending stripped-down instrumentation with heartfelt vulnerability.

David’s plan is simple yet ambitious: to build a strong EP’s worth of music that resonates with listeners and sparks meaningful connections. By releasing singles every few months, he hopes to gradually gain feedback, identify his audience, and refine his approach to self-promotion. The ultimate goal? To book live shows, from intimate gatherings to larger tours, and cultivate a loyal fan base.

“I want to know who my listeners are and what connects with them,” Raine says. “Music has always been personal to me, but now I want to share it and see where it takes me.”

Five Headed Cobra: Delivering an Alt-Rock Punch with “Screaming From The Mountain” 

Five Headed Cobra continues to make waves with their distinct, high-energy sound, blending raw power with dynamic intricacy. The band’s latest offerings, Screaming From The Mountain and Beast Brain, deliver a captivating experience for lovers of the genre, showcasing their ability to craft tracks that are both intense and innovative.

This track stands out for its explosive energy and intricate details, making each listen a discovery of its own. Built on scratchy guitars and driving rhythms, Screaming From The Mountain offers a faster-paced sound punctuated with power-packed nuances. The result is a dynamic, adrenaline-fueled track that captivates from start to finish, pulling listeners into its electrifying atmosphere.

For fans of alternative rock, this song is a straightforward yet richly layered offering. Its immediate appeal gives way to deeper intrigue, culminating in a finale that feels both natural and thrilling.

entry.title: Ben Rowley’s Search for Meaning in Sound
entry.summary: Super Pyramid's Grand Entrance If This Is Paradise!: Ben Rowley's Quest for Significance in Sound Ben Rowley never did abandon…
entry.content:
Super Pyramid's Grand Entrance If This Is Paradise!: Ben Rowley's Quest for Significance in Sound

Ben Rowley never did abandon hope of it. The Vancouver-born composer, songwriter, and producer for Super Pyramid literally hit the road for a bike tour of Canada before settling in Montreal to reignite his creative flame. There, among a tight-knit community of like-minded musicians, he started to write the ambitious debut album Comment if This Is Paradise!—an album that is intimate and outward-facing all at the same time.

The album, released on September 3rd, traverses wide emotional and sonic terrain. Rowley combines traditional 20th-century songcraft with fearless experimentation, challenging the listener to reside in the crossroads: joy and despair, memory and lucidity, lush strings and ice-cool electronic glow. The result is airy and detail-rich, recalling touchstones such as the psychedelic intimacy of Tame Impala, McCartney-era solo self-sufficiency, and Rufus Wainwright's baroque ornamentation.



Many of the album's somber atmosphere are a product of the chaos that went into its making. A breakup tinged the lyrics with heartbreak and loneliness. The pandemic broke up Rowley's band arrangement, sending his collaborators to British Columbia. And in a stroke of bad fortune that borders on farce, he got a concussion after being hit by falling ice while clearing snow. Forced to work in fits and starts, he'd find himself lying across the studio couch, waiting for symptoms to abate before resuming work. "There's a quote from Louise Glück that I think is the nearest thing to attempting to say what this record is about," Rowley says. "'The fundamental experience of the writer is helplessness.' I believe helplessness is the fundamental human experience."

In spite of these difficulties, Comment if This Is Paradise! is not at all compromised. Its production is cinematic and heavy, in great measure because of the addition of Isaac Symonds of Half Moon Run, one of its most important supporting contributors whose string work and vocal processing add depth to the album's color. Rowley and Symonds constructed something epic but close, each song revealing another conception of the same basic quest for meaning.

The eclecticism of the album is present in the singles: Before & After You grandly announces itself with a sweeping orchestral gesture, dissolving past and future in shimmering harmonies and misty piano; Better Angels bounds along on bounding tambourines and percussion, bringing heavy themes to life with lightness of touch; and Slow & Easy eases, quietly at first, into a kaleidoscope of strings and horns, half-Lennon demo and half-Pet Sounds glory. By Never Better, with its stark introspection and tolling bells, we can see Rowley's questioning of lyrics: the quest for meaning continues, but one by one we're forced to live in doubt.

And the title—Comment if This Is Paradise!—sounds imperative, challenge, unanswerable question. Rowley does not define paradise for us; rather, he constructs a solid world in which beauty and desire and contradiction are intertwined, and he invites us to wonder in the instant.

What emerges is an album that feels both personal and universal, the sound of one artist wrestling with the unknowable while opening his inner world outward. Super Pyramid’s debut doesn’t give us certainty—it gives us wonder. And in that vast unknowing, Rowley invites us to linger, listen, and search together.
